title.value: Map of Clean Energy Resources and Projects (CERP) in Canada

about.value:
Map of Clean Energy Resources and Projects (CERP) in Canada

Overview

The Map of Clean Energy Resources and Projects (CERP) in Canada is an interactive map for learning about Canada’s extensive clean-energy resources and projects. By definition, clean energy comprises renewable energy, electric vehicles, nuclear energy, biofuels, and carbon capture and storage (CCS). The latter (CCS) is considered as clean energy since it can significantly reduce global CO2 emissions resulting from fossil-fuel–based power generation and from emission-intensive industrial processes such as oil refining and the production of iron and steel, cement, and chemicals.

This interactive map is composed of several map layers, which show the location of clean-power–generating facilities, bioheat-generation facilities, carbon-capture-and-storage (CCS) facilities, clean-energy projects that are planned or under construction, clean-energy test centres, and clean-energy research-and-development projects, as well as the energy potential of biomass, geothermal, reservoir-hydro, river-current, solar, tidal, uranium, wave, and wind resources. Each of these map layers is described below.

Clean Energy Generation and Projects

Clean Power Generation – Biomass

This map layer shows the locations of Canada’s biomass power-generating stations. These stations have been categorized on the basis of their power-generation capacity. The threshold for this map layer is 0.25 MW (megawatts). This threshold was chosen to reflect the differences in utilization rate, availability factor, conversion efficiency, and capacity factor between bioenergy, wind, hydro, and solar energy systems.

Bioenergy is a renewable energy resource derived from biomass and biomass fuels. The term ‘biomass’ encompasses all organic materials of biological origin, which can be sourced from various operations, including forestry and arboriculture; agriculture and horticulture; and aquaculture.

Data Source: Natural Resources Canada. 2016. Clean Generating Stations (compiled from federal, provincial, and company information). Ottawa.

Clean Power Generation – Hydro

This map layyer shows the locations of Canada’s reservoir-hydro and run-of-river power-generating stations. These stations have been categorized on the basis of their power-generation capacity. The threshold for this map layer is 0.80 MW.

Hydroelectric stations have been developed where the geography and hydrography were favourable; provinces producing large quantities of hydroelectricity include Quebec, British Columbia, Newfoundland-and-Labrador, Manitoba, and Ontario.

Hydropower provides Canadian households and businesses with a clean, reliable, and renewable source of electric power, converting up to 95% of available energy into electricity.

Data Source: Natural Resources Canada. 2016. Clean Generating Stations (compiled from federal, provincial, and company information). Ottawa.

Clean Power Generation – Nuclear

This map layer shows the locations of Canada’s nuclear power plants. These stations have been categorized on the basis of their power-generation capacity. All nuclear facilities in Canada are above the 500 MW threshold.

Nuclear energy produces approximately 16% of Canada’s electricity, and in 2015 accounted for 33% of electricity generated in New Brunswick and over 50% of Ontario’s electricity. It is one of the few technologies that provide reliable baseload electricity without emitting greenhouse gases, complementing other clean and renewable energy sources.

Canada has developed a unique nuclear reactor technology called CANDU, for CANada Deuterium Uranium. All nuclear generating stations in Canada operate CANDU reactors. The 19 operational reactors in Canada (18 in Ontario and one in New Brunswick) are fueled by natural uranium mined from high-grade deposits located in Saskatchewan. Canada is the world’s second-largest producer and exporter of uranium, representing over 20% of world production.

Data Sources:

CANDU Owners Group. COG members, total installed capacity of CANDU reactors.

NB Power. About Us: Nuclear. https://www.nbpower.com/en/about-us/divisions/nuclear

Clean Power Generation – Solar

This map layer shows the locations of Canada’s solar-energy power-generating stations. These stations have been categorized on the basis of their power-generation capacity. The threshold for this map layer is 0.80 MW.

Presently, grid-connected solar-power generation in Canada is carried out primarily in Ontario.

Solar-energy technology comprises thermal and photovoltaic (PV) technologies. Solar photovoltaic technology converts the sun’s rays into electricity. Concentrated PV technology uses optics such as lenses or curved mirrors to concentrate a large amount of sunlight onto a small area of solar photovoltaic (PV) cells or thermal collectors to generate electricity.

Data Source: Natural Resources Canada. 2016. Clean Generating Stations (compiled from federal, provincial, and company information). Ottawa.

Clean Power Generation – Tidal

This map layer shows the locations of tidal-energy power-generating stations in Canada. These stations have been categorized on the basis of their power-generation capacity. The threshold for this map is 0.80 MW.

Presently, North America has two tidal-barrage energy plants, both of which are located in Nova Scotia: one at Annapolis Royal, with a generating capacity of 20 MW of electricity, and the other at Cape Sharp, with a generating capacity of 2 MW.

There is additional opportunity for large-scale tidal-energy projects in Canada. The world’s highest tides occur in the Bay of Fundy. Research and development is underway to capitalize on the untapped tidal-energy potential in Canada.

Data Source: Natural Resources Canada. 2016. Clean Generating Stations (compiled from federal, provincial, and company information). Ottawa.

Clean Power Generation – Wind

This map layer is an illustration of Canada’s wind-energy power-generating stations. These stations have been categorized on the basis of their power-generation capacity. The threshold for this map layer is 0.80 MW.

There are wind farms in the ten provinces and the three territories, with Ontario having the largest capacity, followed by Quebec and Alberta.

Canada’s geography makes it ideally suited to capitalize on large amounts of wind energy. Among other applications, wind energy is being used in wind-diesel hybrid power-generation systems to reduce reliance on diesel generation used in remote communities and in mining.

Data Source: Natural Resources Canada. 2016. Clean Generating Stations (compiled from federal, provincial, and company information). Ottawa.

Major Clean Energy Projects (planned or under construction)

This map layer shows the locations of Canada’s major clean energy projects that are currently under construction or for which construction is planned to be initiated within the next ten years. Major projects are defined using a capital cost threshold of $20 million.

Data Source: Natural Resources Canada. Major Projects Inventory (August 2016). Ottawa: Strategic Policy and Results Sector.

Small-scale and Distributed Generation

This map layer visually represents aggregate statistics on small-scale–generation projects (<0.80 MW for solar, wind, and hydro and <0.25 MW for biomass) and distributed-generation renewable-energy projects in each province and territory.

Various small-scale, grid-connected and off-grid renewable projects are being established in Canada, including in areas that either rely on traditional fossil-fuel–based energy generation or do not presently have access to electricity.

Data Source: Natural Resources Canada. Small-scale and Distributed Generation (compiled from federal, provincial, and company information). Ottawa.

Carbon Capture and Storage (CCS) Facilities

This map layer shows the locations of Canada’s three commercial-scale CCS projects: the Saskpower Boundary Dam project, the Shell Quest project and the Weyburn-Midale project.

Proponents of Canada’s large-scale CCS demonstration projects include SaskPower, which constructed the world’s first commercial CCS project at the Boundary Dam coal-fired power plant; Shell Canada, which launched the Quest CCS project at an oil-sands upgrader in Alberta; and Cenovus Energy, which has been operating the largest monitored CO2 location in the world at a depleted oilfield at Weyburn-Midale (Saskatchewan).

Data Source: Natural Resources Canada. Carbon Capture and Storage Projects. Ottawa: CanmetENERGY, 2015.

Bioheat Generation Facilities

This map layer shows the locations of bioenergy installations in various facility types across Canada that use solid biomass fuels to generate heat (bioheat).

The types of facilities shown on this map include schools, campuses, institutional and commercial buildings, and farm buildings. In recent years, the Northwest Territories, British Columbia, Prince Edward Island, and Quebec have seen significant increases in the use of biomass fuels and the production of bioheat. Growth is particularly strong for space heating in the commercial, institutional, and agricultural sectors (e.g. schools, campuses, communities, and greenhouses).

Solid biomass fuels that are typically used in bioheat-generation facilities in Canada include wood pellets and wood chips. Woody biomass from forestry and arboriculture operations is by far the most common biomass resource available in Canada. Forest harvesting and wood processing leave behind biomass as by-products and residues. These by-products and residues are used as raw material in the production of solid biomass fuel such as wood chips, wood pellets, and wood briquettes.

Data Source: Natural Resources Canada. Bioheat Installations. Ottawa: Bioenergy Systems; Canadian Forest Service, 2016.

Clean Energy Test Centres

This map layer shows the locations of Canada’s clean-energy test centres and laboratories that provide research and development (R&D) support in technology areas such as renewable energy, energy storage, smart grids, micro grids, and residential energy systems.

Data Source: Natural Resources Canada. Clean Energy Test Centres. Ottawa: CanmetENERGY, 2015.

Geothermal Heating Facilities

This map layer shows the locations of geothermal-heating installations in various facility types across Canada. The types of facilities shown on this map include community clubs/arenas, museums, and institutional and commercial buildings.

Data Source: Natural Resources Canada. Geothermal Heating Facilities (compiled from federal, provincial, and company information), 2016. Ottawa.

Clean Technology Incubators and Accelerators

This map layer shows the locations of incubators and accelerators in Canada that provide support and services to enterprises focused on clean technologies (and on various other technologies, in some cases). Accelerators provide seed funding and time-limited support to start-up teams, using structured programming and mentorship services designed to accelerate high-potential firms to success or failure. Incubators cater to early-stage entrepreneurs, providing longer tenure for participating firms and a broader suite of services in terms of access to physical space and mentorship.

Data Source:
Canadian Acceleration and Business Incubation (CABI) Association. Online directory.

DEEP Centre. Accelerating Canada’s start-up ecosystem: a review of Canadian business accelerators and business incubators. Waterloo: DEEP Centre, 2015.

Natural Resources Canada. Clean Technology Incubators and Accelerators (compiled from federal, provincial, and company information), 2016. Ottawa.

Research, Development and Demonstration Projects

This map layer shows the locations of Canada’s most notable government-directed efforts in the research, development, and demonstration (RD&D) of emerging energy technologies. These energy RD&D projects may increase energy efficiency, improve the management of existing generation, and/or develop and demonstrate the potential to harness energy resources if previously infeasible. Projects may take place across communities, within proponent laboratories, or at specialized demonstration sites. These types of projects provide the basis for the long-term deployment of clean electricity technologies. This includes development of cleaner fossil fuels and related environmental technologies.

Data Sources:

Natural Resources Canada. ecoENERGY Innovation Initiative Research and Development (R&D) Projects. http://www.nrcan.gc.ca/energy/funding/current-funding-programs/eii/4987

Natural Resources Canada. ecoENERGY Innovation Initiative Demonstration Projects. http://www.nrcan.gc.ca/energy/funding/current-funding-programs/eii/4989

Natural Resources Canada. Renewable Energy and Clean Energy Systems Demonstration. http://www.nrcan.gc.ca/energy/funding/current-funding-programs/cef/4953

Natural Resources Canada. Large Scale CCS Demonstration Projects. http://www.nrcan.gc.ca/energy/funding/current-funding-programs/4951

Natural Resources Canada. Clean Energy Fund and ecoENERGY Innovation Initiative projects. Ottawa: Office of Energy Research and Development, 2015.

Clean Energy Potential Maps

Biomass Resource Potential

This map layer is an illustration of Canada’s biomass-energy resource potential. It includes two views: Agriculture and Forestry.

The agriculture material on this map is the available straw from cereal crops (wheat, oats, barley) after cattle-usage and soil-sustainability requirements have been removed. The above-ground biomass for wheat, barley, and oats is separated into three components: straw, chaff, stubble. About 50% of the total above-ground biomass is chaff and stubble and is not available for exploitation as a result of mechanical and environmental limitations. Of the straw component, soil-conservation requirements and cattle-usage demands have been removed to arrive at the amount of total available cereal straw.

The forestry sublayer comprises three types of data sets: roadside harvest residue, mill residue, and urban wood residue. Roadside harvest residue consists of forest-harvest biomass that is not utilized by industry. This includes only residue originating from large industries that consume at least 100 000 cubic metres of forest trees annually. Mill residue includes nonmarketable sawdust, wood chunks, and bark components that are produced at the mill site when logs are processed into forest products. Again, this includes only residue originating from major forest-industry facilities that consume at least 100 000 cubic metres of forest trees annually. Urban wood residue is a portion of the municipal waste stream, resulting from urban residential and industrial landscaping, construction, renovation, secondary wood-product production, packaging-product and storage-product disposal, and the disposal of wood furnishings.

Data Sources:

Agriculture and Agri-Food Canada. Biomass Agriculture Inventory 1985-2010 (data). Ottawa.

Natural Resources Canada. Biomass Forestry Inventory 2004-2006 (data). Ottawa: Canadian Forest Service.

Geothermal Resource Potential

The undisturbed ground temperature (UGT) for Canada is generated by a simplified correlation. The area covered by the map is from latitude 42°North to 68°North, since most geothermal applications are concentrated in this part of the country. The average error of the ground temperature is less than 1°C. It can be seen from this map that the contours of the ground temperatures indicate a regional variation ranging from −7°C (north) to 12°C (south). For the inhabited regions, the ground temperature ranges from 6 to 12°C. For the same latitudes, temperatures are generally higher in the west compared to the east.

The distribution of deep geothermal resources for Canada was determined through regional mapping of geothermal gradients, depth-temperature profiles, and underlying geological regions to define reservoir types. Resource potential is divided by potential end use of the geothermal resource based on predicted temperatures of produced waters at reasonably economic drilling depths.

Data Sources:

Grasby, S.E., Allen, D.M., Bell, S., Chen, Z., Ferguson, G., Jessop, A., Kelman, M., Ko, M., Majorowicz, J., Moore, M., Raymond, J., and Therrien, R., 2012. Geothermal energy resource potential of Canada; Geological Survey of Canada, Open File 6914, revised edition, 322 p.

Ouzzane, M., Badache, M., Nejad, P.E., and Aidoun., Z., 2016. Recent Advances in Shallow Ground Thermal Energy: Modeling and Developments; Lambert Academic Publishing, Berlin, Germany, 152 p.

Ouzzane, M., Nejad, P.E., Badache, M., and Aidoun, Z., 2015. New Correlations for the Prediction of the Undisturbed Ground Temperature; Geothermics, v. 53, p. 379-384.

Hydro Resource Potential – Reservoir Hydro

This map layer shows the locations of reservoir hydro facilities in Canada.

All regions of Canada have hydropower resources available for development. Quebec has the highest hydropower potential, followed closely by British Columbia.

Reservoir hydro can support the integration of other renewable generation sources, such as variable-power sources like wind or solar power.

Data Source: Global Forest Watch Canada. Large Dams and Reservoirs of Canada (data set). Edmonton, Alberta: Global Forest Watch Canada, 2010.

River Current Resource Potential

This map layer is an illustration of Canada’s river-current–energy or hydrokinetic-energy resource potential. Presently, river-current technologies are envisaged for Alberta, British Columbia, Manitoba, the Northwest Territories, Ontario, and Quebec.

River-current or hydrokinetic facilities use the flow of the river to produce electricity. Unlike traditional hydropower, which uses a reservoir-hydro or diversion structure, river-current approaches use generators installed directly in rivers. They require no diversions, have no storage, and use minimal infrastructure.

Data Source: National Research Council Canada. Stream Reach Hydrokinetic Power (MW). Ottawa: Marine Infrastructure, Energy & Water Resources, 2015.

Solar Energy Resource Potential

This map layer is an illustration of Canada’s solar-energy resource potential. It includes two views: the mean daily global insolation and the global horizontal irradiance (GHI) in Canada.

Canada has plentiful solar-energy resources, with the most extensive resources being found along the southern border of the country. The territories have a smaller potential because of their higher latitude resulting in shorter daylight time during the winter.

Data Sources:

McKenney, D.W., Pelland, S., Poissant, Y., Morris, R., Hutchinson, M., Papadopol, P., Lawrence, K., and Campbell, K., 2008. Spatial insolation models for photovoltaic energy in Canada; Solar Energy, v. 82, no. 11, p. 1049-1061.

Natural Resources Canada. Annual Average Direct Normal Irradiance 1988-2014. Office of Energy Research and Development, 2015.

Tidal Energy Resource Potential

This map layer is an illustration of Canada’s tidal-energy resource potential.

About 190 tidal-power sites have been identified off Canada’s coasts, with a total estimated capacity of 42 000 MW — more than 63% of the country’s annual total electricity consumption. Nunavut has the country’s greatest abundance of tidal resources; British Columbia has the most potential sites.

Tidal energy is produced by the rise and fall of tides from the gravitational influence of the sun and moon. Tidal energy can take two forms: tidal current and tidal range. Canada is pursuing tidal-current energy generation.

Data Source: National Research Council Canada. Tidal Current Mean Potential Power (MW) Estimates. Ottawa: Marine Infrastructure, Energy & Water Resources, 2015.

Uranium Resource Occurrences

This map layer shows deposits, and occurrences of uranium, which is usually found alongside thorium and rare-earth elements. Some of the deposits and occurrences may become economic producers, but only after extensive exploration, economic evaluation, and environmental assessment. In some cases, uranium is a secondary commodity alongside primary thorium or rare-earth element occurrences.

Data Source: Gandhi, S.S., Prasad, N., Chorlton, L.B, Richer, C., and Lentz, D.R., 2015. Canadian U-Th-REE deposit and occurrence database; Geological Survey of Canada, Open File 7854, 1 .zip file; doi:10.4095/297481.

Wave Energy Resource Potential

This map is an illustration of Canada’s wave-energy resource potential. It includes two views: the mean annual wave-power density in Canada and the annual wave energy for the west coast of Vancouver Island.

Wave energy is created by the wind passing over the surface of the ocean. The waters off Canada’s Pacific and Atlantic coasts are rich with wave-energy resources. Roughly 37 000 MW of total mean annual wave power occurs off Canada’s Pacific coast, equal to more than 55% of the country’s annual electricity consumption. The potential capacity off Canada’s Atlantic coast is even greater, at about 146 500 MW, or more than double the current electricity demand. This potential refers to technical potential capacity and not economic potential capacity; therefore, it may never be developed.

The annual average levels of ocean-wave energy in deep water, just off the Continental Shelf, are about 80 kW/m (kilowatts per metre) of wave front on Canada's Atlantic coast, and about 100 kW/m on the Pacific coast.

Currently, wave-technology demonstration projects are underway in British Columbia and Nova Scotia. However, there are no active development projects in Canada at present.

Data Sources:

National Research Council Canada. Mean Wave Power Density (kW/m). Ottawa: Marine Infrastructure, Energy & Water Resources, 2015.

Institute of Integrated Energy Systems (IESVic). Mean Annual Wave Energy Transport (kW/m). Victoria: West Coast Wave Initiative & 2060 Project, 2015.

Wind Energy Resource Potential

This map layer is an illustration of Canada’s wind-energy resource potential.

The Atlantic coast offers the highest wind potential (over 2000 W/m2), with significant potential on the Pacific coast and in Hudson Bay. In addition, there is significant potential for onshore wind energy in southern parts of Alberta, Saskatchewan, and Ontario.

Data Source: Environment Canada. Annual Mean Wind Energy – 80 m Above Ground Level. Ottawa: National Prediction Development, Meteorological Service of Canada, 2015.

Disclaimer and Appropriate Use

This map layer is for informational purposes and has not been prepared for, or would not be suitable for, legal, engineering, or surveying purposes. The geographic data layers are provided as a public resource. Natural Resources Canada makes no warranties, expressed or implied, concerning the accuracy, completeness, or suitability of its data, and it should not be construed or used as a legal description. Every reasonable effort has been made to ensure the accuracy and completeness of the data.

Users of this information should review or consult the primary data and information sources to ascertain the usability of the information. Natural Resources Canada provides these data in good faith and shall in no event be liable for any incorrect results, any lost profits and special, indirect or consequential damages to any party, arising out of or in connection with the use or the inability to use the data herein or the services provided. Natural Resources Canada shall not be held liable for any third party’s interpretation of the data. Natural Resources Canada reserves the right to change or revise published data and/or these services at any time.
